sections.title: SOURCES
sections.content_md:
The **Sangam Age** is a landmark in the history of South India. The word 'Sangam' is the Tamil form of the Sanskrit 'Sangha', meaning an assembly or association. The Sangam Age refers to the period when Tamil literature was composed by scholars and poets in three successive literary gatherings called **Sangam**, which took place between the first century BC and the second century AD in the kingdom of Pandyas. These texts were composed and compiled in assemblies of poets held in Madurai.

*   **First Sangam:** Believed to have been attended by Gods and legendary sages including Sage Agastya, but all its works have perished.
*   **Second Sangam:** Attended by several poets. Only **Tolkappiyam** by **Tolkappiar** (the oldest book of Tamil grammar) has survived.
*   **Third Sangam:** Attended by many poets and produced a vast literature, of which a fraction survived. This fraction constitutes the extant body of **Sangam literature**.

The themes of Sangam literature are the wars and heroic deeds of the three kingdoms of **Cheras**, **Pandyas**, and **Cholas**.

sections.title: Tirukkural
sections.content_md:
**Tirukkural** is one of the most celebrated works of the eighteen minor works (**Patinenkilkanakku**) of the Sangam literature. It was written by **Tiruvalluvar**, a Tamil poet and philosopher.

*   It is considered a compound of the teachings of the **Dharamashastra**, the **Arthashastra**, and the **Kamasutra**.
*   It comprises a series of brief metrical proverbs on many aspects of life and religion, organized as a collection of Tamil couplets in **133 chapters**.
*   Each chapter covers a specific subject, from "ploughing a piece of land" to "ruling a country", and preaches simplicity and truth.
*   The 133 chapters are grouped into three sections:
    *   (a) **Aram** (righteousness): Discusses ethical living in private life.
    *   (b) **Porul** (wealth): Deals with public affairs.
    *   (c) **Inbam** or **Kamam** (pleasure): Discusses ethical living in private life.

[Image: Thiruvalluvar]

Additionally, Tamil literature comprises five epics: **Jivakachintamani**, **Manimekalai**, **Silappadikaram**, **Valayapathi**, and **Kuntalakeshi**. These epics are a source of information about music, dance, administration, and the grandeur of Kings.

sections.title: Megaliths
sections.content_md:
**Megaliths** are box-like structures erected with stone slabs, resting on each other without any mortar. They acted as either **burial sites** or **commemorative memorials**.

*   Some megaliths are on the surface, while others are underground. Stone circles or boulders on the surface likely served as signposts to the burial site.
*   Some megaliths contain more than one skeleton, indicating that people from the same family were buried in the same place at different times. They are also known as **memorial stones**.
*   They contained not only skeletons but also **grave goods** like pottery and iron objects, which provide insight into the life of people during the Sangam Age.
*   **Inferences from Megaliths:**
    *   The smaller number of agricultural tools compared to hunting and fishing tools suggests that the megalithic people did not initially practice advanced agriculture.
    *   Religious beliefs can be inferred. For example, the presence of **tridents** in graves indicates faith in Lord Shiva.

Renowned historian **Champakalakshmi** identified the Sangam Age with the last phase of the megalithic culture in the Tamil region. She correlated the **velir settlements** from literature with megalithic sites. This period's subsistence base consisted of agriculture, cattle rearing, fishing, the use of iron, and frequent warfare.

[Image: Megalith Burial]

[Image: Megaliths]

**Note on Modern Threats to Megalithic Sites:** Ancient structures face threats from modern construction and unauthorised excavations. For example:
*   The 'pillared dolmen' (locally 'Pandava Gullu') near Tirupati, estimated to be 2,500 years old, was nearly damaged by granite mining.
*   An endangered megalith monument in Palem village (locally 'Devara Yeddhu') has been damaged by treasure hunters.
*   A 'stone circle' megalithic burial site in Venkatapuram has been damaged by the installation of a mobile tower.

sections.title: TAMIL KINGDOMS
sections.content_md:
The Sangam poems mention the term **‘muvendar’**, a Tamil word meaning 'three chiefs', used for the heads of the three ruling families: the **Chera**, **Chola**, and **Pandya**. In addition to these three kingdoms, there were also local chieftains.

[Image: Emblems of Three Tamil Kingdoms]

sections.title: CHERA KINGDOM
sections.content_md:
*   **Territory:** Mostly comprised the present state of Kerala.
*   **Titles:** Chera kings were known by titles such as **Vanavar**, **Villavar**, and **Malaiyar**.
*   **Dynasties:** There were two important lines of Chera Kings, one starting from **Udiyan Cheralathan** and the second from **Irumporai**.
*   **Capital:** **Vanji**
*   **Chief Port:** **Thondi**
*   **Symbol:** **Bow and arrow**
*   **Most Popular King:** **Cheran Senguttuvan**. Information about him is found in the Sangam works, **Padirruppattu** and **Ahananuru**.
*   **Achievements of Cheran Senguttuvan:**
    *   His brother, **Illango Vadigal**, composed the Tamil epic **Silappadikaram**.
    *   He led an expedition to the Himalayas, crossed the Ganges, defeated his enemies, and hoisted the Chera flag.
    *   He brought a stone from the Himalayas to build a temple dedicated to **Kannagi** (the ideal wife).
    *   He started the **Pattini cult**, the worship of Kannagi.
*   **Other Kings:** **Padirrupattu** lists other Chera kings, including **Cheralathan**, **Peruncheral Irumporai**, and **Kanaikkal Irumporai**.

sections.title: CHOLA KINGDOM
sections.content_md:
*   **Territory:** Comprised the present Thanjavur and Tiruchirappalli districts.
*   **Names in Literature:** Referred to as **Chonadu**, **Kaveri Nadu**, etc., indicating rich water resources from the river **Kaveri** which made the soil fertile.
*   **Capital:** **Uraiyur**
*   **Second Capital & Chief Port:** **Kaveripoompattinam** (or **Puhar**)
*   **Symbol:** **Tiger**
*   **Surnames:** Chola kings had surnames like **Killi**, **Valavan**, **Senni**, and **Cholan**.
*   **Most Popular King:** **Karikalan**.
*   **Achievements of Karikalan:**
    *   He was a great warrior who defeated the Chera and Pandya kings at **Venni**.
    *   He defeated a confederacy of nine princes and extended his kingdom beyond Kanchipuram.
    *   He encouraged the growth of agriculture and commerce.
    *   He built the dam called **Kallanai** across the river Kaveri for irrigation.
    *   He fortified the port-city of **Puhar** and made it his capital, which became a great centre for trade.
    *   He was a generous patron to Tamil poets.

sections.title: PANDYAN KINGDOM
sections.content_md:
*   **Territory:** Comprised the present districts of Madurai, Tirunelveli, and Ramanathapuram.
*   **Titles:** Pandya kings were known as **Maran**, **Valudhi**, and **Chezhiyan**.
*   **Capital:** **Madurai**
*   **Chief Port:** **Korkai**
*   **Symbol:** **Fish**
*   **Patronage:** The Pandyan kings were famous for their patronage of the Tamil Sangam. Their capital Madurai was the capital of Tamil language and literature.
*   **Important Rulers:**
    *   **Mudhukudumi Peruvazhthi:** Performed many sacrifices to celebrate his victories.
    *   **Ariyappadaikadantha Neduncheliyan:** A famous ruler who mistakenly gave a death sentence to Kovalan, the hero of Silappadikaram.
    *   **Thalaiyalanganathu Nedunchezhiyan:** He defeated the combined forces of Chera, Chola, and other local chieftains at **Thalaiyalanganam**. He patronised poets like **Mangudi Maruthanar**.

The Pandya rule, along with the Cheras and Cholas, ceased in the third-century AD.

sections.title: LOCAL CHIEFTAINS
sections.content_md:
Apart from the three main kingdoms, several local chieftains, known as **Velirs**, ruled in different parts of Tamil Nadu.

*   The most famous were the **Seven Patrons** or **Kadaiyelu Vallalgal**: **Pari, Ori, Malayan, Elini, Pegan, Aay, and Nalli**.
*   These chieftains extended patronage to Tamil poets, who in turn praised their generosity.
*   They also helped resolve disputes between rulers. For example, the poet **Avvaiyar** acted as a diplomat in the court of **Adhiyaman**.
*   Poet **Kapilar** took care of **Pari's** daughters after his death.
*   These chieftains played a significant role in the political, social, and cultural domains of the Sangam Age.

sections.title: SOCIETY
sections.content_md: The Sangam literature provides a true picture of the society in the Sangam Age, where caste divisions and tribal arrangements existed side by side.

sections.title: SOCIAL CLASSES
sections.content_md:
The social distinction in Tamil Sangam society was primarily based on the division between the **high born** and the **low born**.

*   **Tolkappiyam** mentions four castes, showing Sanskritic influence: **Brahmanas**, **kings**, **traders**, and **farmers**. However, the larger society remained largely casteless.
*   **Brahmanas:** A respectable and learned community that performed caste duties, served as judicial officers, priests, and astrologers.
*   **Vaishyas and Vellalars:** Trade was common to both.
    *   **Vellalars** were landed aristocrats who cultivated wetlands, held high offices with the kings, and also carried out trade.
*   **Uzhavar:** Ordinary ploughmen.
*   **Kadasiyar** and **Adimai:** Landless labourers.

**The Tinai Concept:** The land was divided into five geographical divisions called **tinais**, each with a distinct mode of human adaptation and social group:
1.  **Kurinji** (hilly backwoods): Inhabitants were hunters and gatherers.
2.  **Palai** (parched zones): Inhabitants lived by plunder and cattle lifting.
3.  **Mullai** (pastoral tract): Inhabitants subsisted on shifting agriculture and animal husbandry.
4.  **Marutam** (wet land): Inhabitants subsisted on plough agriculture.
5.  **Neital** (littoral land): Inhabitants were dependent on fishing and salt extraction.

There are also references to full-time craftsmen like **goldsmiths**, **blacksmiths**, and **potters**.

sections.title: FOOD AND DRESS
sections.content_md:
**Food:**
*   Chief articles of food were grain, meat, and fish, along with vegetables, milk, and milk products.
*   Grain was husked and converted into flakes (**aval**).
*   **Appam (apupa)**, a rice-cake soaked in milk, was a luxury.

**Dress:**
*   Clothing consisted of two pieces of cloth.
*   Women in high society used corsets and hair paste.
*   Ornaments were worn by both men and women.
*   Children wore a necklace of tiger teeth.

sections.title: ENTERTAINMENT
sections.content_md:
*   Music and dance were popular forms of entertainment.
*   In villages, **cock-fighting** and **goat-fighting** were common.
*   **Gambling** was practised widely.
*   **Wrestling** was a common sport among the youth.

sections.title: POSITION OF WOMEN
sections.content_md:
The status of women in Sangam society was not equal to that of men. The society had different kinds of women:

*   Married women who were dutiful housewives.
*   Female ascetics of Buddhist or Jain traditions, like **Kaundi Adigal** and **Manimegalai**.
*   A large number of courtesans.

However, women enjoyed freedom of movement. The presence of many women poets is proof that women were provided with good education.

The worship of **Kannagi** or **Pattini** ('the Chaste Lady') was a very early institution. It became popular with the Chera ruler **Senaguttuvan** and spread to places like Sri Lanka and Malwa.

[Image: Statue of Kannagi]

sections.title: MARRIAGE
sections.content_md: There is little information about marriage during the Sangam Age. Later works like the **Tolkappiyam** and the **Kalaviyal** state that the Aryans introduced the rituals and ceremonies of marriage (**karanam**). These works also refer to the eight forms of marriage known to the Sanskrit Dharmashastras.

sections.title: ECONOMY
sections.content_md:
The economy during the Sangam Age was simple and self-sufficient. The people were industrious and believed in living well by earning wealth.

Sangam literature indicates the existence of both the wealthy and the poor.
*   **The wealthy** included kings and those who surrounded them.
*   **The poor** were farm and casual labourers or wandering minstrels.

The division of society into rich and poor was accepted as natural, with poverty considered to be the result of a person's past actions.

sections.title: AGRICULTURE
sections.content_md:
Agriculture was the main occupation.

*   **Crops:** The main crop was **rice**. Other crops included cotton, ragi, sugarcane, pepper, ginger, cardamom, turmeric, cinnamon, and various fruits.
*   **Irrigation:** The state undertook the construction of embankments and canals for irrigation.
*   **Regional Specialities:**
    *   **Chera** country was noted for its jackfruit, pepper, and turmeric.
    *   In the **Chola** country, a piece of land yielded a large amount of paddy.
    *   Sangam poems describe rural activities like cultivating ragi and sugarcane, making sugar from cane, and harvesting grain.

sections.title: OTHER OCCUPATIONS
sections.content_md:
After agriculture, **spinning** and **weaving** were the most widely practised crafts.

*   Spinning and weaving of cotton and silk had reached a high degree of perfection. Spinning was a part-time occupation for women.
*   Weavers could create complex patterns on cloth and silk.
*   **Uraiyur** was a major centre of cotton trade. Poems describe cotton cloth as being as thin as a snake's skin.
*   Scissors and needles were known.
*   The priestly class also used cloth made of wood fibre.
*   **Dyeing** was a widespread ancillary industry.
*   Other occupations included: **ship-building, metalworking, carpentry, rope-making, ornament-making, tanning, and making of ivory products**.

sections.title: TRADE
sections.content_md:
Trade, both internal and foreign, was well-organised and brisk.

**Internal Trade:**
*   Conducted by caravans of merchants using carts and pack-animals.
*   Mostly carried on by **barter**. **Paddy** was the most commonly accepted medium of exchange, especially in rural areas. Salt was sold for paddy, and vice versa. Honey and roots were exchanged for fish oil.
*   There were established markets called **angadi** in bigger towns. Hawkers also sold goods house-to-house.

**Foreign Trade:**
*   There was extensive trade with foreign countries.
*   **Exports:** Pepper, ginger, cardamom, cinnamon, turmeric, ivory products, pearls, and precious stones.
*   **Imports:** Horses, gold, and glass.
*   Port cities like **Puhar** were centres of foreign trade. Other important ports mentioned in poems were **Saliyur** (Pandya country) and **Bandar** (Chera country).
*   **The Periplus of the Red Sea:** This text provides information on the trade between India and the Roman Empire. It mentions important west coast ports like **Naura** (Cannanore), **Tyndis** (Ponnani), and **Muziris** (Cranganore). It also mentions **Uraiyur** as a centre where pearls were sent for export and notes that a great quantity of muslin was made in the Andhra region.
*   The discovery of gold and silver **Roman coins** in the interior of Tamil land indicates the extent of this trade.
